Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Consortium for Embedded Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Full Center Proposal for an I/UCRC for Embedded Systems

0856090 Arizona State University; Sarma Vridhula
0856039 Southern Illinois University at Carbondale; Spyros Tragoudas

Embedded systems are application specific computing systems that have and continue to permeate across every facet of human and machine interaction. Home appliances, mobile hand-held devices, medical instrumentation, etc are just a few examples where embedded computing systems are found today. The proposal is to establish a Center to conduct research on robust, energy efficient and networked embedded systems. The lead of the proposed Center will be Arizona State University (ASU)) with site location at Southern Illinois University at Carbondale (SIUC). The main activities of the proposed Center will encompass fundamental, industry relevant research, education and training for undergraduate and graduate students through research projects and directed industry sponsored internships, and technology transfer made possible by shared IP arrangements and student employment. The formation of the proposed Center will significantly enhance the existing research collaboration and greatly leverage the research capabilities of the participating institution and industrial partners.

The research activities at the proposed Center would have direct contribution to the following broad domains: Health Care, Homeland Defense, Energy and Environment, and Education and Culture. The proposed Center will encourage collaboration, and the research will expose students and faculty to state-of-the-art research projects of value to the industry. Graduate and undergraduate students at the participating universities and engineers from the various industrial members will benefit from the I/UCRC infrastructure and industry-driven research and development projects. Both schools have an excellent track record of getting under-represented populations involved in science, engineering and mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Center for Embedded Systems’ research focuses on the technologies that enable sensing, communications, computing, and control in everyday things.

Project Outcomes

 When a patient’s wrist sensor sends a real-time report to a doctor‘s cell phone, embedded systems make it happen and people’s lives are better. As commuters travel across the same bridge each day without danger, their safety is secure partly in thanks to the low-power wireless sensor circuits monitoring its performance and reporting for repair any inconsistencies. Productivity in our daily lives is centered on smart phones that can run more applications, on longer battery life, in thinner formats, without becoming hot to the touch.

 The Center conducts the fundamental research that helps companies put these types of improvements to work in these application areas:

  • personalized healthcare technologies
  • consumer electronics
  • aerospace / avionics
  • industrial automation
  • automotive & transportation
  • security

An embedded system is an application-specific computing system that is embedded inside a product. Home appliances, mobile hand-held personal systems (cell phones, health monitors, assistive devices, cameras, electronic games), instrumentation, automobiles, aircraft, missiles, satellites, assembly equipment and nuclear power plants, are just a few examples in which to find embedded systems. They are distinguished from general purpose computing systems by their well-defined functionalities, stringent design constraints based on how they will be used, and the fact that they encompass all of the four fundamental operational capabilities required to interface to the world at large, namely, sensing, computing, control and communication, which can now be integrated with single chip multi-processors. This has opened up unprecedented and unforeseen possibilities for this type of computing. The Center for Embedded Systems’ industry-relevant -- but fundamental -- research is critical for companies developing products to meet market need.

 Broader Impacts

The Center’s work improves the energy efficiency of embedded systems hardware and software; improves and expands battery powered devices for medical applications and consumer electronics, and can also significantly improve the energy efficiency of high performance servers, thereby reducing the damage to the environment. Similarly, the Center's work in verification of hybrid systems is being used to ensure that control systems in automobiles will operate correctly. The same technologies will be used in all sorts of safety critical systems, and societal benefits of this line of work cannot be overstated. The Center's  work on sensors for monitoring bridges is yet another example of the far reaching societal benefits of its research program.

 Results

In its first five years, the Center for Embedded Systems (through two academic sites, Arizona State University and Southern Illinois University) has funded 78 research projects, 63 faculty members, and 151 students. Results include 99 publications, 15 products, and on-going collaboration with electronics industry leaders such as Qualcomm, Intel, Raytheon, Toyota, Marvell, UTC Aerospace Systems, Rockwell Collins, General Dynamics, Johnson Controls, and more.
